p: Pentagalloyl glucose is a hydrolysable tannin with a high antioxidant activity due to the numerous phenolic hydroxy groups in its structure. Its properties include anti-inflammatory, anti-bacterial, antidiabetic, and anti-cancer properties. It is able to inhibit DNA replication, cause cell cyle arrest in the G1 and S phases, and elicit apoptosis ( Zhang et al., 2009). This compound stands out due to its ability to bond to proteins, especially those with a high-proline content like collagens, via hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic forces. This property makes pentagalloylglucose a candidate in the treatment of vascular disease ( Patnaik et al., 2019). The ability to precipitate bacterial proteins translates into an intense bacteriostatic effect, combating both Gram-positive and Gam-negative bacteria like: methicillin-resistant and quinolone-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus mutans, Escherichia coli, and Pseudomonas eruginosa ( Cho et al., 2010).
